meanings.definition: To provide or use less than is needed or expected
meanings.sent1: She had to skimp on ingredients for the recipe because she ran out of flour.
meanings.sent2: Don't skimp on studying for the test if you want to do well.
meanings.sent3: He tried to skimp on paying the bill, but the waiter caught him.
meanings.sent4: The company decided to skimp on safety measures, leading to a serious accident.
meanings.sent5: It's never a good idea to skimp on sleep; your body needs rest to function properly.

meanings.definition: To be stingy or frugal with something
meanings.sent1: My aunt always skimps on gifts, giving us cheap trinkets for birthdays.
meanings.sent2: Some people skimp on tipping at restaurants, which is not fair to the servers.
meanings.sent3: He tried to skimp on sharing the snacks, but his friends noticed.
meanings.sent4: She tends to skimp on compliments, rarely acknowledging others' achievements.
meanings.sent5: The boss would never skimp on bonuses for hardworking employees.

meanings.definition: To do something hastily or carelessly
meanings.sent1: I had to skimp on cleaning the house before guests arrived, so it wasn't very tidy.
meanings.sent2: Don't skimp on proofreading your essay; you might miss important errors.
meanings.sent3: He decided to skimp on wrapping the gift, using newspaper instead of proper wrapping paper.
meanings.sent4: The chef had to skimp on seasoning the dish, resulting in a bland taste.
meanings.sent5: She had to skimp on rehearsing her lines for the play, so she stumbled during the performance.
